conclusion: Let’s analyze the motion of objects A and B using the provided velocity-time (v-t) graphs and determine if their accelerations are first increasing and then decreasing over the time interval from 0 to t1.
The graph shows velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis for two objects, A and B.
The time interval of interest is from t = 0 to t = t1.

Both objects follow a parabolic path, with object A’s graph being a downward-opening parabola (velocity starts at 0, increases to a maximum, then decreases back to 0 at t1) and object B’s graph being a similar shape but positioned below A’s.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. Mathematically, acceleration a is the derivative of velocity with respect to time: a = dv/dt.
On a v-t graph, the acceleration is the slope of the graph at any point.
The question asks if the acceleration of both objects is first increasing and then decreasing during the interval [0, t1].
Both graphs are parabolas that open downward.
For object A: At t = 0, velocity v = 0. The velocity increases, reaches a maximum at some point between t = 0 and t = t1, and then decreases back to v = 0 at t = t1.
Object B follows a similar pattern but with a lower peak velocity compared to A.

premise: Since the parabolas are symmetric (as they start and end at v = 0), the maximum velocity occurs at the midpoint of the interval, i.e., at t = t1/2.
conclusion: The maximum velocity occurs at the midpoint of the interval, i.e., at t = t1/2.

premise: Since acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph, we need to examine how the slope changes over the interval [0, t1].
conclusion: The slope (acceleration) starts positive and decreases as the curve flattens at the peak.

premise: At t = t1/2, the slope is 0 (since the tangent is horizontal at the maximum).
conclusion: At t = t1/2, the slope is 0.

premise: From t = t1/2 to t = t1, the slope becomes negative and continues to decrease (becoming more negative) as the curve steepens downward.
conclusion: From t = t1/2 to t = t1, the slope becomes negative and continues to decrease.
